items.description: Upper Bristol Avon area
items.message: High river levels today may lead to flooding. Flooding is possible on 16 February 2026 and throughout this week. River levels at the Fosseway, Brokenborough, Great Somerford and Dauntsey gauges remain high but are currently stable or falling. Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the Bristol Avon, Tetbury Avon, Sherston Avon, Dauntsey Brook, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected, particularly around low lying areas in Tetbury, Badminton, Brook End at Luckington, Corsham, Lacock and the road at Reybridge. Light rainfall is possible on Monday and Tuesday but conditions may worsen on Wednesday and Thursday. We are closely monitoring the situation and will issue further alerts and warnings if required. Please avoid using low lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 12:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

Levels are currently falling in the upper reaches of the River Ray, however, we expect river levels to continue slowly rising at Islip overnight and tomorrow. Levels will remain high and sensitive to further rainfall over the coming days.

items.message: High river levels today, 16 February 2026 may lead to flooding. This information is correct as of 15:00 on Monday 16 February 2026. The causeway at Sutton Gault has approximately 54cm of water on the road. The causeway at Welney has up to 47cm of water on the road. The causeway at Earith has approximately 2cm of water on the road. Due to the uneven surface of the roads, water may be deeper in places. The Environment Agency are liaising with Norfolk Highways who will decide whether to close the Welney road. For more information about the causeway at Welney, please visit the 'Welney Flood Watch' Facebook group. Please note that the content of this group does not represent the views of the Environment Agency. We are not expecting the situation to escalate, or to issue any further warning messages at this time. The forecast is dry tomorrow We are monitoring rainfall and river levels. items.description: Combe Haven
items.message: River levels are higher than normal in Crowhurst and Bulverhythe, but falling following Sunday's rain. Only isolated showers are forecast Monday and Tuesday, river levels should continue to fall. River levels should return near to normal in Crowhurst by Tuesday. However widespread rain is forecast Wednesday morning. Potentially more rain than recorded on Sunday. items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors around Muchelney and Thorney
items.message: The River Yeo level is 8.75m and is stable. The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.48m and is stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping has paused at Huish Episcopi and will resume when river levels allow. Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week. Catchments are saturated and rivers very responsive to the forecast rainfall. items.message:
High tides on Tuesday may lead to flooding.

Further flood alerts may also be in place for Wednesday and Thursday high tides. Areas most at risk include Christchurch Harbour and tidal stretches of the Lower Stour and Avon. The detailed tidal forecast for those who use it is - the first forecast high water of 1.20 mAODN is at 09:14AM, which is 0.42m above tide tables, with north westerly force 4 winds. The second forecast high water is at 09:45PM with a level of 1.25mAODN with easterly force 5 winds. (mAODN is height above average sea level.) 
We are closely monitoring the situation .

items.description: Lower Tone and Parrett Moors
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.42m and is rising as a result of overnight rainfall. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.38m and is stable. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For the latest levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has paused as a result of overnight rainfall and will resume when river levels allow. Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week.   
We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and sluices. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 17/02/2026.

items.description: Curry Moor and Hay Moor
items.message:
The River Tone level at Currymoor pumping station is 7.42m and is rising as a result of overnight rainfall. Water will enter Currymoor via Hookbridge spillway whilst above 7.45m. The drain level at Currymoor pumping station is currently 7.38m and is stable. Cutts Road and New Road remain closed. Athelney spillway is running and the A361 is closed. For the latest levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has paused as a result of overnight rainfall and will resume when river levels allow. Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week.   
Catchments remain saturated and rivers are very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation closely and checking flood banks, spillways and sluices. Please avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 17/02/2026.

items.description: Aldingbourne and Barnham Rifes
items.message: The Aldingbourne Rife is high following weeks of rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads, and land at Riverside Caravan Centre will continue. The Barnham Rife has returned to normal. Only isolated showers are forecast on Monday and Tuesday. The Aldingbourne Rife should not rise much further, before beginning to fall slightly by 2:00PM on 16/02/2026. However, widespread rain is forecast on Wednesday morning (18/02/2026). If as much rain falls as is currently predicted, from Wednesday afternoon flood impacts could affect Barnham Road and Lake Lane, and isolated properties on Marshall Close, Barnham. Flooding could affect the car park at Tescos on Shripney Road. River levels should peak by 12:00PM on 19/02/2026 in Barnham, but not until 8:00PM on 19/02/2026 in Bersted. Unsettled weather could continue throughout February. We are clearing debris screens through Barnham. Our pumps at Felpham are running. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Avoid roads that flood (Barnham Road and Lake Lane). This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17/02/2026.

items.description: River Lox

Only isolated showers are forecast on Monday (16/02/2026) and Tuesday (17/02/2026). River levels should continue to fall, and levels should return near to normal by Tuesday evening. However, widespread rain is forecast on Wednesday morning (18/02/2026). If as much rain falls as is currently predicted, from 6:00PM on 18/02/2026, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and possibly isolated riverside properties at Loxley Bridge on Wrotham Hill, Dunsfold and Petworth Road, Chiddingfold. Also gardens near Brewhurst Mill on Brewhurst Lane and the Onslow Arms, Loxwood. River levels should peak, and begin to fall, by 8:00PM on 19/02/2026, returning near to normal by Friday (20/02/2026). Unsettled weather could continue throughout February. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have. Continue to operate private water control structures at Brewhurst. This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17/02/2026.

If as much rain falls as is currently predicted, from 8:00PM on 18/02/2026, flooding could affect fields, rural roads, and possibly gardens of Tanbridge Park, Blackbridge Court, Arunside School Fields, gardens of mill properties between Broadbridge Heath and Billingshurst, and near Pallingham Lock. River levels should peak, and begin to fall by 4:00PM on 19/02/2026 in Horsham, but not until 6:00AM on 20/02/2026 near Pallingham Lock. Unsettled weather could continue throughout February. Our automatic sluice at Provender Mill is operating to reduce flood risk. Consider activating any flood protection products you may have in Wanford. This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17/02/2026.

items.description: River Thames for Shiplake, Lower Shiplake and Wargrave
items.message:

Flooding is expected on 16 February 2026 into 17th February 2026.

Flooding of property and roads is possible tomorrow, especially in the Basmore Lane, Bolney Road and Loddon Drive areas and surrounding Lower Shiplake and Wargrave areas. River levels will continue to rise, in response to yesterday's heavy rainfall. Levels will remain high over the next few days. Further patchy rain is forecast  over the next 12 hours.

We are closely monitoring the situation. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities. 

Stay away from flood water - it contains hidden dangers such as open man hole covers, sewage and chemicals. Don't put yourself or others at risk.

This message will be updated by 10am on 17 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Longacre borehole in the Lambourne Valley. We expect levels to rise over the next few weeks and levels remain sensitive to further sustained rainfall. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others.

items.description: Mansbridge and Woodmill on the River Itchen
items.message:
High river levels are expected to cause flooding on Monday. 
Flooding is expected on 16 February 2026 due to a combination of high river flows and high tides.   
High tide is forecast at 22:45 16/02/2026 and 00:45 17/02/2026. The water level is expected to be 4.65 metres Chart Datum (1.91 mAOD). Flooding could affect the access road and car parking areas near the White Swan Pub and car garage at Mansbridge. Some water may be forced up through the floor of the Pub. Parts of Riverside Park will also be flooded. The next high tide, forecast at 10:45 17/02/2026, is expected to be 10cm lower. Flooding impacts are possible, but not expected on this tide. However, flood risk will increase from Wednesday 18/02/2026, as more rain, possibly heavy, is forecast. 
We are checking rivers for blockages and liaising with Southampton City Council on operation of Woodmill. 
Activate any flood protection products you may have , including defences around the White Swan Pub. 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.message:

Further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast on Wednesday 18/02/2026. If this affects the area, further properties will experience cellar flooding, and a small number may experience ground floor flooding later this week.

items.message:

We expect levels to continue to rise slowly over the coming days and levels remain sensitive to further rainfall. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 

We are closely monitoring rainfall and groundwater levels.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed. Take particular care when driving through flood water both for your own safety and to prevent flooding to others. 

This message will be updated by 12:00PM, on the 17 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and Parrett, Upper Reaches

floodArea.riverOrSea: River Yeo, River Parrett, River Cary

items.message:
Considerable floodwater remains on the Somerset Levels and Moors. Upstream catchments are saturated and are very responsive to rainfall, and consequently the risk of flooding continues. Areas most at risk include locations near the River Yeo, River Parrett and River Cary, with low lying land and roads expected to be most affected particularly around the Ilchester to Yeovilton road at the end of runway. 
Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week.     
We continue to monitor the situation and Field Teams are out clearing debris screens and checking rivers for blockages. Take care and avoid walking, cycling or driving through flood water. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions and don’t put yourself or others at risk. This message will be updated by 1pm on 17th February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Yeo and River Parrett Moors, low lying properties around Muchelney
items.message:
The River Yeo level is 8.75m and has risen due to overnight rain. The drain level at Huish Episcopi Pumping Station is 8.48m and is stable. Flooding affects the Langport to Muchelney road when this drain level exceeds 7.3m, the Muchelney to Long Load road above 7.86m, the Muchelney to Thorney road above 7.93m and the Muchelney to Drayton road above 8.8m. Property flooding is possible above 8.35m. For the latest river and drain levels refer to https://check-for-flooding.service.gov.uk/river-and-sea-levels. Pumping has paused at Huish Episcopi and will resume when river levels allow. Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week.   
Catchments are saturated and rivers are very responsive to the forecast rainfall. We continue to monitor the situation and check flood banks and spillways. Avoid driving through flood water. This message will be updated by 1pm on 17/02/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Salt Moor and North Moor including Moorland
items.message:
Water levels in Saltmoor and Northmoor remain high today, Monday 16 February. The Northmoor Main Drain Remote is 4.27m and is falling. The level in Currymoor is stable and still high. Athelney spillway continues to run into Saltmoor and Northmoor. We are pumping at Northmoor and Saltmoor and have additional mobile pumps at both stations. Pumping at Currymoor has paused as a result of overnight rainfall and will resume when river levels allow. Showers, heavy at times, will persist through Monday (16/02/26) before clearing through this evening. Tuesday will be a largely dry day with a return to more unsettled conditions later in the week.   
Catchments are saturated and rivers very responsive to rainfall. We are monitoring the situation and checking floodbanks and spillways. Remain aware of local water levels and weather conditions. This message will be updated by 1pm on 17/02/26 or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in Denton
items.message: Groundwater is high, close to the surface, but now slowly falling at the Houndean Bottom borehole. Despite Sunday's rain. Widespread rain is forecast Wednesday. There is uncertainty in rainfall amounts. Between 10mm and 40mm. If the smaller amount of rain occurs, groundwater levels could continue to fall. If the maximum rain occurs, groundwater levels will likely rise again. Either way, groundwater flood impacts could continue all week. Probably until March. Springs will appear, water will affect fields, the recreation ground, and a small number of cellars in Denton. If as much rain occurs as predicted on Wednesday, groundwater could rise until 23/02/2026, perhaps longer, and a small amount of water may appear on Denton Road, may flow towards Vicarage Close and affect areas near the three ponds in South Heighton. The weather outlook remains unsettled into March, although perhaps with rain less often. Take care on roads that flood (Denton Road). Ensure pumps work. We will monitor, and update this message by 18:00 20/02/2026.

On Wednesday (18/02/2026) further rain, possibly heavy, is forecast to affect Hampshire. If this affects the valley, then all ongoing flooding impacts will increase. Sewerage system impacts could also be possible. Groundwater levels are expected to remain high for much of February. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 6:00PM on 23 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Lavant
items.message: The River Lavant is high following weeks of rain. Minor flood impacts affecting fields, roads and gardens will continue. In East Lavant, water may affect Sheepwash Lane, Pook Lane, the Green, and bridges across the river. Only isolated showers are forecast on Monday (16/02/2026) and Tuesday (17/02/2026). River levels should not rise far, but will not fall far either. Widespread rain is forecast on Wednesday morning (18/02/2026). If as much rain falls as is currently predicted, river levels could rise by 30cm. From Wednesday afternoon, flooding could affect isolated properties in East Lavant and Westhampnett. River levels should peak by 12:00PM on 19/02/2026. River levels will still not fall far though. Unsettled weather could continue throughout February. We are operating structures in Westhampnett for the Flood Alleviation Scheme. Don't put yourself or others at risk. Avoid roads that flood (Sheepwash Lane). Report blockages to 0800 80 70 60. This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17/02/2026.

We are closely monitoring the situation. We are liaising with emergency services and local authorities.

Stay away from flood water - it contains hidden dangers such as open man hole covers, sewage and chemicals. Avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.

This message will be updated by 10am on 17 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year and have now reached a level where communities may be affected by groundwater flooding within the next few days. We expect groundwater levels to continue slowly rising over the next few weeks due to sustained rainfall across the area. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer.

Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed.

Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible from 10th February 2026. 
Groundwater levels are currently rising at our Farringdon borehole near Alton. Groundwater levels are above normal for this time of year. We expect levels to rise over the next few weeks due to sustained rainfall across the area. Due to the nature of groundwater flooding, this situation could continue for several weeks or longer. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Residents are advised to prepare property resilience measures and ensure that pumps are working where they have been installed . 
This message will be updated by 8:00PM on 17 February 2026 or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Coln from Fossebridge to Quennington
items.message:
High river levels on the River Coln may cause flooding. 

River levels are high on the River Coln following recent rainfall. Flooding of property and roads is expected, especially nearest the River Coln in the Fossebridge area. Further showers of rain are possible overnight. Tomorrow is forecast to be predominantly dry. River levels are expected to remain high and sensitve to any further rain over the coming days.

We are closely monitoring the situation. 

Activate any flood protection products you may have. Go to River levels online for updates on current river levels.  Stay away from flood water - it contains hidden dangers such as open man hole covers, sewage and chemicals.  

This message will be updated by 11:00AM on the 17 February 2026, or as the situation changes.

items.description: Groundwater flooding in East Kent
items.eaAreaName: Kent, South London and East Sussex
items.message:
Rising groundwater levels may lead to flooding. 
Flooding is possible to low lying land, roads and properties with basements around these areas, 
Petham Bourne, Alkham bourne and Nailbourne including Alkham, Elham, Barham, Bishopsbourne, Bridge, Patrixbourne and Bekesbourne. Groundwater levels in East Kent have been rising following significantly wetter conditions since January. Levels are continuing to increase in February in response to heavy rainfall. 
We are closely monitoring the situation . 
Keep up to date with groundwater levels on the 'Check for Flooding' site on gov.uk . Riparian owners are reminded to keep rivers on their land clear. 
This message will be updated by 4:00PM on 20 February 2026 or as the situation changes.
